articles.headline: With Combative Style and Epithets, Trump Takes America First to the U.N.
articles.snippet: In a bellicose speech before world leaders, President Trump framed differences with North Korea, Iran and Venezuela as a battle of good versus evil.
articles.abstract: In a bellicose speech before world leaders, President Trump framed differences with North Korea, Iran and Venezuela as a battle of good versus evil.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Trump brought the same confrontational style of leadership he has used at home to the world’s most prominent stage on Tuesday as he vowed to “totally destroy North Korea” if it threatened the United States and denounced the nuclear agreement with Iran as “an embarrassment” that he may abandon.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Mexico Earthquake Kills Hundreds, Trapping Many Under Rubble
articles.snippet: In Mexico City, where a school collapsed, ordinary citizens used their bare hands to try to free the students trapped in the rubble.
articles.abstract: In Mexico City, where a school collapsed, ordinary citizens used their bare hands to try to free the students trapped in the rubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A powerful earthquake struck Mexico on Tuesday afternoon, toppling buildings, killing children in a school that collapsed, rattling the capital and sending people flooding into the streets for the second time in just two weeks.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple, Paulina Villegas and Elisabeth Malkin

articles.headline: Trump Offers a Selective View of Sovereignty in U.N. Speech
articles.snippet: The president declared that nations should respect each other’s sovereignty. But he threatened to act aggressively against some nations, like North Korea and Iran.
articles.abstract: The president declared that nations should respect each other’s sovereignty. But he threatened to act aggressively against some nations, like North Korea and Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Trump, in declaring Tuesday that sovereignty should be the guiding principle of affairs between nations, sketched out a radically different vision of the world order than his forebears, who founded the United Nations after World War II to deal collectively with problems they believed would transcend borders.

articles.headline: Unemployment Is So 2009: Labor Shortage Gives Workers an Edge
articles.snippet: Earnings are rising at a pace not seen in almost two decades. Will it be enough to draw more people off the bench and into the job market?
articles.abstract: Earnings are rising at a pace not seen in almost two decades. Will it be enough to draw more people off the bench and into the job market?
articles.lead_paragraph: Is a new golden age for the American worker around the corner?

articles.headline: Senate Republicans Embrace Plan for $1.5 Trillion Tax Cut
articles.snippet: Senate Republicans, abandoning a key fiscal doctrine, agreed to move ahead on a budget that would add to the federal deficit in order to pave the way for a $1.5 trillion tax cut.
articles.abstract: Senate Republicans, abandoning a key fiscal doctrine, agreed to move ahead on a budget that would add to the federal deficit in order to pave the way for a $1.5 trillion tax cut.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans, abandoning a key fiscal doctrine, agreed on Tuesday to move forward on a budget that would add to the federal deficit in order to pave the way for a $1.5 trillion tax cut over the next 10 years.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Republican Leaders Defy Bipartisan Opposition to Health Law Repeal
articles.snippet: Senator Lamar Alexander gave up on his effort to shore up health care markets as his fellow Republicans pressured lawmakers to back the latest Affordable Care Act repeal.
articles.abstract: Senator Lamar Alexander gave up on his effort to shore up health care markets as his fellow Republicans pressured lawmakers to back the latest Affordable Care Act repeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Eleven governors, including five Republicans and a pivotal Alaskan independent, urged the Senate on Tuesday to reject a last-ditch push to dismantle the Affordable Care Act.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Before Wisconsin, Foxconn Vowed Big Spending in Brazil. Few Jobs Have Come.
articles.snippet: The Taiwanese company’s manufacturing model has not translated easily to other countries, where it faces different social, political and labor conditions.
articles.abstract: The Taiwanese company’s manufacturing model has not translated easily to other countries, where it faces different social, political and labor conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the Taiwanese manufacturing giant Foxconn pledged to spend $10 billion and create 13,000 jobs in Wisconsin, the company made a similar promise in Brazil.

articles.headline: Apple Watch Series 3 Excels, Even if You Don’t Need Cellular
articles.snippet: Date night without your iPhone? That’s now doable with the new cellular Apple Watch, which for the first time can be untethered from your smartphone. Here’s our review.
articles.abstract: Date night without your iPhone? That’s now doable with the new cellular Apple Watch, which for the first time can be untethered from your smartphone. Here’s our review.
articles.lead_paragraph: To understand why you might want the new cellular Apple Watch, put yourself in the shoes of a wealthy person who drives a weekend car. (I promise this is a fun exercise.)

articles.headline: Trump Pushes to Revisit Iran Nuclear Deal, and Asks Allies to Help
articles.snippet: With a deadline looming, the president seeks support from allies to toughen provisions of the pact rather than scrap it, with mixed reaction from Europeans.
articles.abstract: With a deadline looming, the president seeks support from allies to toughen provisions of the pact rather than scrap it, with mixed reaction from Europeans.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump is seeking to revisit the nuclear agreement with Iran to toughen its provisions rather than scrap it right away as he has threatened, enlisting allies to pressure Tehran to return to the negotiating table, administration officials said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Rick Gladstone
